overview: VS Code 1.109 (January 2026) emphasizes a more operational 'agent experience' (sessions, delegation, customization, and trust controls) alongside notable workbench and terminal additions. The notes also include several Preview/Experimental features and configuration options for teams.

detailed_explanation.title: Chat UX and debugging model/tool behavior
bullets: Adds controls around 'thinking' display for supported models, including a compact/detailed presentation (`setting(chat.thinking.style)`).
Tool-call failures can auto-expand for easier debugging (`setting(chat.tools.autoExpandFailures)`).
Includes UI refinements intended to make it easier to follow interleaved model reasoning and tool usage.

detailed_explanation.title: Agent session management
bullets: Improves starting and switching between different agent session types and surfacing agent status in the UI (for example via an indicator in the command center; `setting(chat.agentsControl.enabled)`).
Enhances the sessions list UX (resizing, multi-select bulk operations, and improved navigation in stacked views).
Adds support for handing off work between agent types (for example planning locally and implementing elsewhere).

detailed_explanation.title: Customization and governance
bullets: Introduces `/init` to help generate or update workspace instructions based on repository conventions.
Agent Skills are described as generally available and enabled by default (`setting(chat.useAgentSkills)`), with tooling for creating/configuring skills.
Adds organization-wide instruction support (`setting(github.copilot.chat.organizationInstructions.enabled)`) and diagnostics for loaded customization resources.
Adds controls that affect how custom agents are invoked and whether they can be used as subagents.

detailed_explanation.title: Extensibility: subagents and MCP Apps
bullets: Highlights subagent patterns (context isolation, specialization, and potential parallelism).
Adds support for MCP Apps that can render interactive UI in chat responses.
Mentions additional agent-provider options (for example Claude Agent in Preview) and registry configuration options for MCP packages.

detailed_explanation.title: Trust and safety for terminal tooling
bullets: Introduces terminal sandboxing (Experimental) to constrain file-system and network access for agent-run commands (`setting(chat.tools.terminal.sandbox.enabled)`).
Improves terminal tool lifecycle control (backgrounding, explicit timeouts, and await/kill support for background terminals).
Expands the set of commands that can be auto-approved when auto-approve is enabled (still user-configurable).

detailed_explanation.title: Workbench: integrated browser (Preview)
bullets: Adds a new integrated browser (Preview) intended for a fuller browsing experience (including sign-in), beyond iframe limitations.
Can open localhost links in the integrated browser (`setting(workbench.browser.openLocalhostLinks)`) and optionally replace Simple Browser (`setting(simpleBrowser.useIntegratedBrowser)`).

detailed_explanation.title: Engineering/ecosystem notes
bullets: Deprecates the GitHub Copilot extension; AI features are delivered by GitHub Copilot Chat and the deprecated extension is uninstalled on update.
Mentions additional platform packaging improvements and extension API updates/proposals relevant to chat and model-provider configuration.

key_changes: More visible and controllable 'thinking' and tool failure UX in chat.
Improved agent session management (switching/delegation, bulk operations, status indicator).
Agent Skills generally available and enabled by default; `/init` for bootstrapping repo instructions.
Organization-wide instructions and better diagnostics for customization resources.
Terminal sandboxing (Experimental) and expanded terminal tool lifecycle controls.
Integrated browser (Preview) for localhost/web workflows within VS Code.
GitHub Copilot extension deprecated in favor of GitHub Copilot Chat.
impact: Agent-heavy users: less friction managing many sessions and delegating between agent types.
Teams: more ways to enforce consistent AI behavior via org and workspace instructions and shared skills.
Security-conscious users: sandboxing and clearer terminal tool controls can reduce risk from automated command execution.
Web developers: integrated browser can consolidate local testing and inspection inside VS Code.
Extension/MCP authors: richer chat surfaces (MCP Apps) enable more interactive experiences.
caveats: Several features are explicitly Preview/Experimental and may require enabling settings; availability may vary by channel.
Terminal sandboxing is described as affecting macOS/Linux; it does not apply universally across all platforms.
The notes include references to sample projects and external links; these are illustrative rather than official support commitments.
insights: The release notes treat agent workflows as a first-class operating model: session lifecycle, delegation, governance, and trust are recurring themes.
The combination of skills + org instructions suggests VS Code expects AI usage to be configured like other dev tooling, not left to ad-hoc prompting.
Safety features are moving toward enforceable constraints (sandboxing) in addition to UI confirmations.
